passage_text: Lots of children with learning difficulties are visual learners and this is often the case with autistic children. Difficulties with the auditory processing system can make attaching meaning to sounds a complicated business. This is why a visual approach to learning can be very effective for children with autism.
Best Answer: The ability to talk depends on the severity of autism. I've worked with a two year old who was way behind in language, and with alot of work he was talking by three.

Children with autism, also known as autism spectrum disorder or ASD, have social, communication and language problems. They also have restricted and repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities, such as flipping objects, echolalia, or excessive smelling or touching of objects. Autism may be mild or severe.

Other chidlren with autism may be able to talk but have deficits in expressive language, which they understand what other people are saying, but can't find the words to express themselves and often these children rely on scripts or echolalia.

Several early behaviors build a foundation for language. These abilities have also been linked to whether a child can anticipate another person's mental state and use that understanding to explain and predict behavior. Developing this theory of mind may be a central difficulty for children with autism.

As we know, each individual autistic child presents with their own particular mixture of abilities and challenges. Therefore, there is no “one-fix-suits-all” solution when it comes to helping children impacted by autism in learning language.

AAC may even help children learn to talk. Children with autism may to like the way foods look, taste, or smell. They may not like how some foods feel in their mouth. Your child may. 1  refuse new foods; 2  avoid foods with different textures, colors, or tastes; 3  eat a limited number of foods.

There is no cure for autism, but early and intensive treatment can help children with autism improve their behavior, communication and social skills. Treatment may include support and facilitation, behavior modification, educational therapy, and medicine.

Recent studies, however, indicate that as many as 80 percent of children with autism can learn to talk. One such study in 2006 showed that toddlers who received intensive therapy aimed at developing foundational oral language skills made significant gains in their ability to communicate verbally.
